title: Filing personal chapter 7 but own a 1 person corporation. Will my income for means test be salary paid to me or corp. income?
question: The business isn't really worth anything without my involvement and skill. The specials skills that I personally teach is the product sold. So, I have my corporation cut me a paycheck. How do I calculate what my income is for means test purposes? Is it going to be my paycheck? Or just every bit of profit the corp made including my paycheck? Please provide some insight.
answers: All sources of income are relevant and must be disclosed. Hire a lawyer.

How carefully does your corporation handle its money? Does the corporation debit card get used to pay your personal expenses, like a fill up of your personal vehicle at Arco or to buy breakfast at Norms that can't be supported by IRS business use? The term for this is called "piercing the corporate veil." The better you manage your books, the better your chance of having just your pay be your Sch J and Means test income. Hope this perspective helps!
What is your income as shown on your income tax return? That's what I would use.

This will depend on your Trustee.
Your salary is a good starting point; and may very well be the end of it.
If there are substantial retained earnings which exceed what is reasonable for working capital, etc. (and which, by the way, increases the value of your shares in the corporation), your Trustee may want to impute some of that to you as well.

You didn't give enough info to give you a definitive answer. How do you figure your taxes? Is your corporation an S Corp, an LLC or a C Corp? Most small companies are LLCs or S Corps. If one of those, you should probably include all revenue to the corp then deduct business expenses.

Of most of your debt is business related you may mitt have to worry about the means test. Make sure you talk about that when you consult with an attorney.
